generif.text: ROMK1 is a substrate of PKC and that serine residues 4 and 201 are the two main PKC phosphorylation sites that are essential for the expression of ROMK1 in the cell surface
One disease-causing mutation in the ROMK channel truncates the extreme COOH-terminus and induces a closed gating conformation.
In a heterozgous Bartter syndrome patient, AA exchanges Arg338Stop & Met357Thr in ROMK exon 5 alter the C-terminus of the ROMK protein & can affect channel function.
Findings support the proposed role of ROMK channels in potassium recycling and in the regulation of K+ secretion and present a rationale for the phenotype observed in patients with ROMK deficiency.
NH(2)-terminal phosphorylation modifying a COOH-terminal ER retention signal in ROMK1 could serve as a checkpoint for proper subunit folding critical to channel gating.
ROMK is antagonistically regulated by long and kidney-specific WNK1 isoforms
molecular mechanism for stimulation of endocytosis of ROMK1 by WNK kinases
A novel mutation in KCNJ1 in a Bartter syndrome case diagnosed as pseudohypoaldosteronism.
CD63 plays a role in the regulation of ROMK channels through its association with RPTPalpha, which in turn interacts with and activates Src family PTK, thus reducing ROMK activity.
Members of the Framingham Heart Study were screened for variation in three genes-SLC12A3, SLC12A1 and KCNJ1 causing rare recessive diseases featuring large reductions in blood pressure.

Five polymorphisms in the KCNJ1 gene coding for the potassium channel, ROMK, showed associations with mean 24-hour systolic or diastolic blood pressure.

Multiple intra- and/or intermolecular interactions of WNK1 domains are at play for regulation of ROMK1 by WNK1 in the kidney.
These results confirm the important role of the acidic motif of WNK4 in its protein-protein interaction with the ROMK channel.

In a large cohort of ante/neonatal Bartter syndrome, deafness, transient hyperkalaemia and severe hypokalaemic hypochloraemic alkalosis orientate molecular investigations to BSND, KCNJ1 and CLCNKB genes, respectively.
hydrophobic leucines at the cytoplasmic end of the inner transmembrane helices comprise the principal pH gate of Kir1.1, a gate that can be relocated from 160-Kir1.1b to 157-Kir1.1b.
KS-WNK1 is an important physiological regulator of renal K(+) excretion, likely through its effects on the ROMK1 channel.

These results suggest that the conformation of the cytoplasmic pore in the Kir1.1 channel changes in response to pHi gating such that the N- and C-termini move apart from each other at pHi 7.4, when the channel is open.
Regulation of renal outer medullary potassium channel and renal K(+) excretion by Klotho.
c-Src inhibits SGK1-mediated phosphorylation hereby restoring the WNK4-mediated inhibition of ROMK channels thus suppressing K secretion.
POSH inhibits ROMK channels by enhancing dynamin-dependent and clathrin-independent endocytosis and by stimulating ubiquitination of ROMK channels.

PI3K-activating hormones inhibit ROMK by enhancing its endocytosis via a mechanism that involves phosphorylation of WNK1 by Akt1 and SGK1.

A KCNJ1 SNP was associated with increased FG during HCTZ treatment.
Findings suggest that 11q24 is a susceptible locus for openness, with KCNJ1 as the possible candidate gene.

Molecular analysis revealed a compound heterozygous mutation in the KCNJ1 gene, consisting of a novel K76E and an already described V315G mutation, both affecting functional domains of the channel protein.
The association between polymorphisms in KCNJ1, SLC12A1, and 7 other genes and calcium intake and colorectal neoplasia risk was studied.

knockdown of KCNJ1 in HK-2 cells promoted cell proliferation. Collectively, these data highlight that KCNJ1, low-expressed in ccRCC and associated with poor prognosis, plays an important role in ccRCC cell growth and metastasis
WNK4 is a substrate of SFKs and the association of c-Src and PTP-1D with WNK4 at Tyr(1092) and Tyr(1143) plays an important role in modulating the inhibitory effect of WNK4 on ROMK

Data suggest underlying pathology for some patients with type II Bartter syndrome is linked to stability of ROMK1 in ERAD pathway; using a yeast expression system, cells can be rescued by wild-type (rat) ROMK1 but not by ROMK1 containing any one of four mutations found in (human) type II Bartter syndrome; mutant ROMKs are significantly less stable than wild-type ROMK. (ERAD = endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation)
endosomal trafficking factors CORVET and ESCRT suppress plasma membrane residence of the renal outer medullary potassium channel

The presence of ROMK protein was observed in the inner mitochondrial membrane fraction. Moreover, colocalization of the ROMK protein and a mitochondrial marker in the mitochondria of fibroblast cells was shown by immunofluorescence.

We replicated the methods in a previous study to detect rare and potentially loss-of-function variants in SLC12A3, SLC12A1, and KCNJ1 reducing blood pressure in variant carriers as compared with noncarriers using whole exome sequencing data. Our study confirmed that SLC12A3, SLC12A1, and KCNJ1 are indeed genes protective of hypertension in the general population.

interpro.desc: Potassium channel, inwardly rectifying, Kir, cytoplasmic

name: potassium inwardly rectifying channel subfamily J member 1
other_names: potassium channel, inwardly rectifying subfamily J member 1
potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily J member 1
summary: Potassium channels are present in most mammalian cells, where they participate in a wide range of physiologic responses. The protein encoded by this gene is an integral membrane protein and inward-rectifier type potassium channel. It is activated by internal ATP and probably plays an important role in potassium homeostasis. The encoded protein has a greater tendency to allow potassium to flow into a cell rather than out of a cell. Mutations in this gene have been associated with antenatal Bartter syndrome, which is characterized by salt wasting, hypokalemic alkalosis, hypercalciuria, and low blood pressure. Multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
